data.content: Pelé, whose full name is Edson Arantes do Nascimento, is a retired Brazilian professional footballer. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest football players of all time. Pelé was born on October 23, 1940, in Três Corações, Brazil. He played as a forward and is known for his exceptional dribbling skills, goal-scoring ability, and overall athleticism. Pelé played the majority of his career for Santos FC in Brazil and later played for the New York Cosmos in the United States. He won three FIFA World Cups with the Brazilian national team in 1958, 1962, and 1970. Pelé is also the all-time leading scorer for the Brazilian national team, with 77 goals in 92 appearances. Throughout his career, Pelé scored over 1,000 professional goals and consistently showcased his talent and skill on the football pitch. He retired from professional football in 1977 and has since been involved in various philanthropic and ambassadorial roles promoting the sport.
Did he ever played for Barcelona?

No, Pelé never played for Barcelona. He spent the majority of his career playing for Santos FC in Brazil and later played for the New York Cosmos in the United States. Although there were rumors and speculation about a potential transfer to Barcelona at one point, it never materialized. Pelé remained loyal to Santos FC throughout his career and did not play for any other professional club.
For how many clubs did he played for?

Pelé played for two professional clubs during his career. He spent the majority of his career playing for Santos FC in Brazil from 1956 to 1974. During this time, he achieved great success and became a national and international star. After leaving Santos FC, Pelé played for the New York Cosmos in the United States from 1975 to 1977. Although he only played for two clubs, his impact and achievements on the football field are legendary.
